turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Forget it!

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: Calm down.  I found it!

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: Battery's dead.  Shit.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Let's go!

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: That thing won't come after us, right?  It's going for bigger game. The group blundering around in the basement.  Poor fools.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Hurry up!

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: Just a minute.  I'm shaking!  Take the gun.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: For Chrissake, I'll do it.  What's the combination?!

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: To the left twice then five no... sorry... I think it's fifteen... it's been a while...

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Oh Jesus...

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Fifteen... what's next?

turns.speaker: CUTHBERT
turns.text: Eight to the right!  Look!  I found it!

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: This huge police presence tonight isn't necessary, Lieutenant.  You'll just scare people off.  I can handle the security behind scenes with this system.  It's state of the art.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: The cops are non-negotiable, Ippolito.  Why don't you just tell me how this space station works.

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: It's fool proof, basically.  I designed this whole thing myself. Every valuable object in the Museum carries a small electronic chip.  If anything's moved so much as an inch, we get an alarm pinpointing the exact location of the attempted theft.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: That's great if you're stopping a burglar.  Not our goal here.  Are there motion detectors?

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: In every exhibition room.  The museum's divided into five cells. The reception and exhibit are in cell five.  We could arm the motion detectors in cells one to four, then seal the perimeter with our fire doors.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: That would leave one exit for hundreds of people.  You'd be violating every fire regulation on the books.  We'll guard the perimeter with my men and engage the motion detectors in the other cells.  One more question.  I see a big hole.  If this entire thing is run by computer, what happens if the power fails?

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: You don't know much about computers, Lieutenant.  There are safeguards built in.  We have back-up systems with redundancies.  There's no way these computers can fail.

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: The whole system is shutting down! We have to get out quickly before the fire doors fall!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: What doors?

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: I told you!  They seal off all the cells.  They were designed to fall automatically in a system failure --

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: You said the system couldn't fail!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Ippolito!  Get back here!

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: Like hell!

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: D'Agosta?  Ippolito.  Come in.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Where the hell are you?

turns.speaker: IPPOLITO
turns.text: I made it outside.  I'll co-ordinate the rescue efforts from here.  Help is on the way.  Just sit tight.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: It's a little late, you son of a bitch.  There's a friggin' monster loose in here!  Get the FBI, the fire department.  Find metal cutters, cut through.  And bring a cannon.  The damn thing is huge.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Who are you?  The undertaker?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Special Agent Pendergast.  FBI.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Vince D'Agosta.  Am I out?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Not at all.  I think we may be working on the same case.  If so, I could use your help.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: The body?

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: What's left of it.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Mind if I have a look?

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: We need light in here, stat.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Where's the head?

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Careful.  That mess on the ground is brains.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Whose footprints?

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Night watchman who found the body. Sweet old man.  Been tossing his cookies for over an hour.  Not a likely suspect.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: An original Roger Tory Peterson of a Red-Breasted Merganser.  Amazing.  I have a copy of this in my office at home.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Can't really focus on birds at the moment, Pendergast.  I'm tryin' to keep my breakfast down.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: In this violent world, I believe the only way to stay sane is to take time to notice beautiful things.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I drink.  After hours of course.  On duty, I smoke.  Do you mind?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Not at all.  I enjoy the smell of a good cigar.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Then you won't like this one.  It's a piece of shit.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Lieutenant --

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Call me Vince.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Did you read about a boat that washed up outside of New Orleans about four months ago?  Twelve bodies on board.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Who didn't?  Big news.  Out of Brazil, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Yes.  That's my case.  Now it's yours. All the corpses were badly mutilated in a very particular way. Decapitated.  Brains extracted.  Limbs torn to shreds.  It looked like the work of a large animal, but there was no sign of an animal on board.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: So the method of death is the only connection?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: No.  There's more.  There were crates from this museum in the hold of the boat.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: If you don't mind, this could be important.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: You're kidding.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Unfortunately, no.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I've got to admit, that was a damn sight better than "the dog ate my homework".

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: How do you explain the part about Beauregard?

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: They heard the victim's name and wove him into their story.  Nice touch.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I believed them.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: You think what we've got here is a monster as big as a house that smells... like hamburger?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: No.  I think what we've got here is a psychotic killer wielding some kind of unusual weapon... who wants us to believe he's a monster.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: What happened to them?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: If you don't mind a suggestion, you might try a saliva test.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Saliva test?  You mean, you think someone ate part of the brain?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Correct.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I don't like animals.  Never have. Dog bit me when I was little.  After that I gave up on pets.  Animals are irrational.  Give me a psychotic killer any day.  If there's one thing that makes me queasy it's being part of a food chain.  My first case as a rookie, two brothers climbed a fence at the zoo.  It was late August.  Over ninety.  The polar bear was inside his cave.  Kids didn't know he was in there.  All they saw was the pool. They got to swimming and splashing. The noise woke up the bear.  By the time I arrived, both little boys were in pieces.  The bear was dragging one kid around by the foot. I can still hear the mother screaming --

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: This isn't an animal, Vince.  I've been on this case four months, remember?  I've learned a few things.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: You've been holding out on me Pendergast.  You have a suspect capable of this?

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: How big is the sub-basement?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Apparently it's huge.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I think I should come with you.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: We haven't got time.  You have to meet with museum security so we can make a decision about tonight.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Pendergast!  Help!  It's right behind us!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: This door's locked.  Try shooting the hinges off.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Vince?  There's no way we can get to you with the fire doors down. There's an entrance to the sub- basement in the hall off the north side exit.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: The sub-basement?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I've been down there.  It links up to the old sewer system.  I can guide you out.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I smell it.  It's here.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Go out the north exit!  There's a hallway and a false wall by the Greek vases.  Run!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Everybody.  Get behind me.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Nice to see you, Lieutenant.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: The sub-basement, huh?  Great idea.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: This place is a maze.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: I'm one of the few who know every inch it, now that John is gone.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Look.  It's some kind of letter.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: May I see that?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Did you hear that?  My God.  He says that Mbwun is real!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Pardon my French, but bull shit.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: This on top of the scratches... isn't it proof!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Shouldn't a drug that powerful be destroyed?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: The virus itself might have positive applications.  They'll keep the plants in secure lock up while the studies are made.  Greg isn't joining us?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Lieutenant!  It's me.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Dr. Green has to see you!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Got my hands full here.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: It's important.  Please.  You have to come!  Pendergast, too.  She's found out something.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: What happened?!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: There's a dead body in the exhibit! People are panicking, trampling each other trying to get out.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: It's still back there!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: How much ammo do we have to make a stand?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: You're asking me?  I don't even know how to load this thing.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: All right.  Kawakita, cover the rear.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Oh shit.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: I believe in you a hundred percent, Vince, but that's the second time we've been at that intersection.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: Not so loud.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: All right everybody, hold up!

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: What does it say?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Dr. John Whittlesley.

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: What's that doing here?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: I don't know.  I thought Dr. Whittlesley died in South America.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Dear God.  Where are we, Lieutenant?

turns.speaker: D'AGOSTA
turns.text: I'd say we're in its home.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: We've met.  The Hacksaw Murders.  '89.

turns.speaker: DR. ZIEWZIC
turns.text: Oh yes!  Who could forget.  Afterwards you sent me that amazing case of Chateau Lafitte.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I hope you liked it.

turns.speaker: DR. ZIEWZIC
turns.text: Lovely bouquet.  After our last case, Vince took me out for a draft beer. As I recall we split the check.

turns.speaker: DR. ZIEWZIC
turns.text: What are we talking about here?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Someone who makes the Hacksaw Murderer look like Mother Teresa.

turns.speaker: DR. ZIEWZIC
turns.text: Right.  The entire brain appears to have been extracted.  May I see it, please?

turns.speaker: DR. ZIEWZIC
turns.text: Curious.  There's something missing.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: The thalamus and the hypothalamus, perhaps?

turns.speaker: DR. ZIEWZIC
turns.text: Yes.  Two organs the size of a walnut have been removed with what looks like surgical precision.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Yes.  Bit of a shock.  But as Cuthbert so tactfully put it, the museum needs new blood.  And since I've been here since the Mesozoic Era --

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Now Margo, don't overreact.  Cuthbert has to cut costs somehow.  My leaving makes perfect sense.  This isn't exactly early retirement.  I've overstayed the party a bit.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: We can't do without you.  You're one of the foremost authorities on primitive pharmacology.  You're practically an institution around here.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: That, apparently, is the problem. I'm yesterday's news.  Who needs a Curator of Plant Biology in a museum with one exhibit on plants?  Monsters and dinosaurs, cannibals and shamans are the new currency of the realm.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Please.  Don't humiliate me further.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Let me help.  I can take care of everything.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: No, Margo.  This is one problem you can't solve.  You have to stay out of it.  The fact is, I want to retire.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How can you say that?  You know it's not true.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Yes it is.  I'm tired and I'm no longer needed --

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: My work on fossil intermediates would be crippled without you.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: With all due respect, dear, that's bull.  You dance rings around me with your new technology.  You've left me in the dust.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Your work is highly relevant.  What about your display on Primitive Pharmacology?  Cuthbert told me himself he was going to feature it prominently in the Superstition Exhibit.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Healing plant use among the Ki tribe of Bechuanaland has been cancelled to make room for Tibetan Erotic Art.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Come on.  I'll walk you back to the elevator.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm not giving up.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: You must.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: This isn't a death sentence.  Greg has promised to teach me fly fishing.  I'll garden.  I'll write.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You are this museum.  It won't be the same without you.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Everyone needs a change of scenery. I've been rolling down these halls for forty-odd years.  That's quite enough.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That Cuthbert.  What a piece of work. Someone's dead and all he cares about is his Superstition Exhibit.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Cuthbert's counting on the exhibition's success.  The museum is in debt.  Contributions and public funding have dried up.  Admissions no longer cover overhead.  The last big infusion of cash we had was the King Tut exhibit.  Cuthbert was hired to get us out of the red.  If the Superstition Exhibit isn't lucrative, he'll have to start auctioning off some of these gems.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: I can't help thinking there's something that Pendergast overlooked.  If the scratches were made by whatever killed Beauregard, it wants something that's in here.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: A blow dart.  Seed pods.  A plant press.  Pretty unimpressive stuff.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Let me see the plant press.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: I'm not sure.  As you know, the Kothoga lived outside civilization on the tepui for thousands of years. Species flourished in isolation when man and pollution rendered them extinct.  This could be one of the last remaining samples of an unknown plant.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Whatever it is, it must be common on the tepui.  John used it as packing material.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: You're right.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Margo, these aren't seed pods.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What are they?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: They're eggs.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Like the claw.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Let's not jump to conclusions.  This egg could belong to any number of reptiles, Dr. Frock.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Come on, Margo.  We're on the verge of something huge.  Let's consider the possibility, just the three of us, alone in this room.  What if John was right.  I mean, what if?  And he sent back an egg of his monster in the crates.  When it got to the museum, it hatched.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Several problems with that theory. For one thing, this egg is intact. For another, according to Pendergast, the crates were shipped here on a boat.  Everyone on board was killed like Beauregard.  If the thing hatched in mid-ocean, where did it go?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Look at this.  An ambyloid reovirus protein.  That explains why the computer's confused.  The plant's infected with a virus.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: That's not so unusual.  Many plants carry viruses.  Like the burls on Maple trees.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: But a virus normally codes for other viruses.  This one's making human and animal proteins.  Listen to this.  "Glycotetraglycine collagenoid. Weinstein's tropic hormone.  4- monoxytocin supressin hormone."

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: All right, assuming the program is accurate, this is a description of the animal with that claw.  "Species unidentified.  Genus: unidentified.  Phylum unknown.  Male, weight in excess of 240 kg.  Brain capacity, 900 centimeters." That means it's highly intelligent. "Quadrupedal."

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Quadrupedal!  The other name for Mbwun.  "He Who Walks on All Fours."

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: "Nocturnal.  External hair and bony plates.  Locomotor speed 60-70 kilometers.  Reduced optic chiasm"... poor eyesight.  "External mucoid nasal glands,"... very keen scent... "Morphological characteristics: Highly robust.  Aggressiveness: extreme."

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: So the claw came from a huge creature with a preternatural sense of smell and poor eyesight that hunts at night.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: With the intelligence of a human being, the speed of a greyhound, and the strength of a grizzly bear.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Margo, what you've just described is a killing machine.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: And it's hungry.  It's been two days since it's eaten.  There are five hundred people arriving right now. The animal hunts at night and it has a keen sense of smell!  All those people in one enclosed space...

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: It's like ringing the dinner bell.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Some kind of power failure.  Maybe it's the storm.  Do you have a flashlight?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Dr. Frock.  Did you hear that?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Don't stop now.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: It's one of the fire doors.  Good Lord, Margo.  We're trapped!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: None of that matters now.  The people upstairs need us.  We have to help.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: We can't.  We've managed to get inside the one place that's safe.  I think we should sit tight and wait for reinforcements.  If we go outside, we're risking more lives. You have to accept it, Margo, there's nothing we can do.  The building must be swarming with police by now.  It won't take long for them to get through the doors.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That thing could kill ten people in a matter of minutes.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: I'm coming with you.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: No, Dr. Frock.  You can't.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Come back and get me.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: We will.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Remember, it has poor eyesight.  It hunts with its sense of smell.  So for God's sake, Margo, don't get those fibers on your clothes!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Dr. Frock?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Look who's here, Margo.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Thank you for taking the time to help us with this, Dr. Frock.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Happy to be useful.  It's rare enough these days.  According to security, Beauregard put the Whittlesley crates in storage area 1012.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: How many storage areas are there?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: They fill seven floors.  We have the largest collection of mammals and dinosaurs in the world.  Just to give you an idea, there are more than three million insects specimens.  Not to mention amphibians, reptiles, birds, anthropological artifacts, meteorites, minerals and gems.  Only about five percent of the museum collection is actually on display.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Do you mean Dr. Whittlesley?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Yes.  John made quite a study of the whole museum.  He had a copy of my original plans.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Something tried to get into this room!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: And failed.  These doors are solid steel.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: This means there must be an animal loose in the museum!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I wouldn't be so sure.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: It's from John.  Those two arrows were his insignia.  It's addressed to Louis Moriarty, a patron who financed his expeditions.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Read it out loud.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: "Dear Louis, Tomorrow we go to the south end of the tepui where we'll be in the greatest danger, so I'm sending Carlos back with the crates.  You always believed in me, Louis, even in the darkest days.  So it gives me great pleasure to tell you your faith has been rewarded.  We've made an incredible find.  I enclose a representation of Mbwun.  Note the exaggerated claws, the reptilian attributes, the hints of bipedalia. It's beyond belief, but this statue is accurate.  I know because I've seen the beast."

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: You said John Whittlesley made a study of your blueprints of the museum.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Are there any hidden rooms or staircases?  Places where someone could hide?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Not really.  Just the sub-basement.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Where is that?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: I don't know.  It was walled over.  No one's been down there in years.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: You said you had plans of the museum.  Could we see them, please?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: We think it may have something to do with the eggs we found in the crate.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: Margo, this is too dangerous.  You always think you can solve everything.  This time you don't have enough information.  The animal might behave in unexpected ways.  Leave her here with me.  Don't put her in danger.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: He's right.

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Footsteps!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Dr. Frock, I was wondering.  What happened to the rest of Whittlesley's plants?

turns.speaker: FROCK
turns.text: They were sent to the Center For Disease Control in Atlanta.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: You work here?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes, I do.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: What do you do?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm an Evolutionary Biologist.  What do you do?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Nothing.  I'm in third grade.  What's a revolutionary what ch'a ma' callit?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Evolutionary Biologist.  I study how life on earth evolved over millions of years.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Way cool.  Then you know where the dinosaurs are.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Fourth floor, West wing, but stay with your class.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: This room sucks.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: She's never going to take us to see the dinosaurs.  That lady said they were on the fourth floor.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Let's ditch and find them ourselves.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: We're not supposed to go back there.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Chicken.  This is a great short cut.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I don't want to go this way.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Don't be a wuss.  Come on.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Quiet!

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: I don't know.  But I think it's bad.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: We were just lost, okay?  And we went down this curvy staircase.  At the bottom was a big shadow.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Big as a house.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Not that big.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Well almost.  Depends which house.  It smelled like old hamburger, and it made this weird noise.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: And it snuffled the ground like a dog.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Like this.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: It had a long tongue, teeth this big and yellow eyes.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: They were green eyes and they were slit like a lizard's.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: They were yellow!

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: You're color blind.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Hard to read in this light.  The ink is so faded.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: The dogs have lost the scent, Mr. Pendergast.  Maybe we should head back.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Not yet.  Let's try the fork to the left.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: They've got something.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Keep the light up.  I can't see.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Shut them up!

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Heel Argo!  Hobbes!  Heel!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Stop!

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Holy mother, what is that?

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Argo!  Hobbes!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Get back!  Now!

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: There's something out there!  Let's go get it now!  That's why we came down here, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: He's right.  Follow me.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Look.  It's Hobbes!  He's all right.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Come on.  Let's get back to the others.  We can't leave them alone.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: It's alright.  I can tell by the way the dog's acting that whatever was out there is gone.  What is this place?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Not on the map.  Looks like it connects with the city sewer.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Oh... my... God!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Quiet.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Jesus, what is this?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Another storage room.

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Oh no.  I smell it.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Keep the animal quiet.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: If I spent half the time on my Fractal Evolution thesis that I spend on this fly rod, I'd have my PhD.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: But at what a price.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I have the species identification on these teeth.  We can extract DNA and start running tests on the extrapolator program.  Call Dr. Frock.  He wanted a demonstration.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Margo, you haven't heard?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Frock's been fired.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That's impossible.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: I'm sorry to be the bearer of bad tidings, but you know me.  Telegraph. Telephone.  Tell Kawakita.  I got the definitive word from Cuthbert's secretary.  This is Dr. Frock's last week.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: For once I'm glad you're rumor central.  What in the world is going on?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Someone's been murdered.  Not shot, strangled or stabbed, either.  Torn limb from limb.  There's talk of a psychotic killer or even an animal.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Mbwun.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: What do you make of it, Margo?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's not mammalian, that's for sure. I think it's reptilian.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Turkish Gecko, I believe.  A lizard.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Lizard DNA and human DNA on the same strand?  Impossible.  The sample must be contaminated.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: There's another possibility.  A lot of repeated base pairs could suggest a high level of genetic damage.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: What kind of egg is it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's reptilian.

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: These plant fibers are loaded with hormones!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What kind of hormones?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: 4-monoxytocin is... "A hormone secreted by the human hypothalamus gland."

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Try Weinstein's tropic hormone.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: This is it.  This is what he, or it... is after!  The plant has high concentrations of the same hormones found in minute quantities in the human brain!

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: So what?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Pendergast told me the killer extracts and eats the hypothalamus and thalamus of the victim's brains!

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Eats them?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes.  Whatever killed Beauregard may have lived on this plant.  When the crates were put in secure storage, they were out of reach.  The killer couldn't get them, so it got the next best thing.
